com.koucha.experimentalgame.rendering

Interface Renderer

  • All Known Implementing Classes:
    GLFWRenderer

    public interface Renderer
    Takes care of creating a window, provides functionality to render Renderable objects to this window and forwards the input received by the Window to a InputBridge

    A minimal setup should always have the form: 

     
 try{
     renderer.init();

     // create window and do your stuff here,
     // exit try block only if program ends

 } finally{
     renderer.cleanUp();
 }

      Cleans up all the resources reserved by the renderer Should be as soon as the renderer isn't used anymore Graphics interfaces used by renderers often work outside of the garbage collector.

      Sets up the renderer HAS TO BE CALLED BEFORE ANYTHING ELSE!

      Sets the renderer up to draw 2D Gui elements (orthographic projection)

      Sets the renderer up to begin the rendering of a new frame
      void initializeUpdateIteration()
      Updates the input provided through the InputBridge

    • Method Detail

      • cleanUp

        void cleanUp()
        Cleans up all the resources reserved by the renderer

        Should be as soon as the renderer isn't used anymore

        Graphics interfaces used by renderers often work outside of the garbage collector. Because of that, this method should be used to avoid memory leaks etc.

      • createWindow

        void createWindow(int width,
                  int height,
                  java.lang.String title)

      • setCamera

        set the camera used to render 3D scenes
        Parameters:

      • setInputBridge

        void setInputBridge(InputBridge inputBridge)
        Parameters:
        inputBridge - receiver of the input captured by the renderer

      • vSyncEnabled

        boolean vSyncEnabled()
        If vertical synchronization (vSync) is enabled finishRenderIteration() will wait for the display to update before returning
        Returns:
        true if vertical synchronization is enabled

      • windowShouldClose

        boolean windowShouldClose()
        Returns:
        true if the window requests to be closed (for example because the user closed it)
